titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John Hosken Papers TAM.735
titlestmt.author: Kate Fisher

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-01-21 16:05:29 -0500.

change.item: Updated to include materials integrated from accession number 2019.032 by Samantha Rowe.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

physdesc.extent: in 1 manuscript box and 1 legal file folder.

did.abstract: John Hosken attended Harvard University from 1969 to 1973. He was a member of the Students for a Democratic Society and the Progressive Labor Party during his years as an undergraduate. The John Hosken Papers consist of flyers and leaflets distributed by the Students for a Democratic Society and the Progressive Labor Party on Harvard Universities campus from 1969 to 1973. These flyers and leaflets called for radical action against the Vietnam War, the Cambridge Project, and social injustice within the communities of Harvard University and Radcliffe College. Flyers advertising meetings advocating for squatters rights within the community of Boston, living wages for the service employees of the University, and mobilization for the 1969 March on Washington against the Vietnam War form the bulk of the collection. The collection also includes a press release, contact list, newsletter, and notes on committee logistics for the event that occurred in April 1989 to mark the 20th anniversary of the 1969 Harvard Building Occupation and Strike.
did.physloc: Some materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of leaflets and flyers collected by John Hosken between 1969 and 1973 in Boston and Cambridge, Massachusetts. This material focuses on the actions of the Harvard University and Radcliffe College branches of the Students for a Democratic Society and the Progressive Labor Party. The flyers and leaflets call for students of Harvard University, as well as the general public, to protest the Vietnam War, advocate for squatters rights in Boston, create a living wage for service employees of Harvard University and Radcliffe College, as well as mobilize the undergraduate students of Harvard University for the 1969 March on Washington against the Vietnam War. The collection also includes a press release, contact list, newsletter, and notes on committee logistics for the event that occurred in April 1989 to mark the 20th anniversary of the 1969 Harvard Building Occupation and Strike.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: John Hosken attended Harvard University from 1969 to 1973. He was a member of the Students for a Democratic Society and the Progressive Labor Party during his years as an undergraduate.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by John Hosken in 2017; an additional accession was donated in 2018 by John Hosken. The accession numbers associated with these gifts are 2018.061 and 2019.032.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; John Hosken Papers; Tam 735; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, materials were placed in new acid-free folders and boxes, and described on the collection-level.
The materials from the 2019 accretion were placed in a new acid-free folder. Where captions were illegible, the archivist's interpretation is enclosed in square brackets.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by John Hosken were transferred to New York University in October 2017 by John Hosken. These materials are governed by a Creative Commons CC0 license, which permits publication and reproduction of materials accompanied by full attribution. See, https://creativecommons.org/licenses/
